turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Get over here.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: MARY
turns.text: Really.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: Yeah? What do you want?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Um, hi, I'm Ted Peloquin. I'm here to take Mary to the prom.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: Prom? You're about twenty minutes late. She just left for the prom with her boyfriend Woogie.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: Jesus Christ, guy, what the hell were you doing?!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I was playing a trick. I-I-I had a baseball.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: What seems to be the situation here? You shit yourself or something?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I wish.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I, uh... I got it stuck.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: You got what stuck?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: It?  Oh it. All right, these things happen, let me have a look. It's not the end of the world.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: OH FOR THE LOVE OF GOD!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Shhhhhh!

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: Shirley, get in here! You gotta see this!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What?! No please, sir --

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: She's a dental hygienist. She'll know what to do.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: Is it the frank or the beans?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I think a little of both.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: One guess.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: How the hell'd you get the beans all the way up top like that?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't know. It's not like it was a well thought-out plan.

turns.speaker: MARY'S DAD
turns.text: You're looking at him. C'mere and take a look at this beauty.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, that's really unneces --

turns.speaker: MARY'S MOM
turns.text: Charlie, that's mean. Come on in, Ted. Don't listen to Mr. Wise Guy here. He's a joke a minute.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh.  Oh, that's a good one.

turns.speaker: MARY'S MOM
turns.text: Teddy, hon, are you okay?  OH HEAVENS TO PETE!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Would you shhh! Mary's gonna hear us.

turns.speaker: MARY'S MOM
turns.text: Just relax, dear. Now, um... what exactly are we looking at here?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MARY'S MOM
turns.text: I mean is it... is it...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, no, please!

turns.speaker: MARY'S MOM
turns.text: Teddy, be brave.

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Ho there.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh God.

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Everything okay here? Neighbors said they heard a lady scream.

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Now I've seen it all. What the hell were you thinking?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I wasn't trying --

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Is that bubble what I think it is?

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Well, there's only one thing to do.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No, no, no, I'll be fine. I'll just hang my shirttail out and work on it in the morning.

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Look, son, this'll only hurt for a second.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No! I was pissing!

turns.speaker: POLICE OFFICER
turns.text: Yeah, I'll bet you all were. Come on, in the truck.

turns.speaker: RENISE
turns.text: Hey.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: So what's up?

turns.speaker: RENISE
turns.text: Eh.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Great. Great.  So listen, uh, I was wondering if maybe you wanted to go to the prom you know, with me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's no big deal, whatever I mean, if you want.

turns.speaker: RENISE
turns.text: See, the thing is, I heard a rumor that this guy I like was gonna ask me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Uh-huh.

turns.speaker: RENISE
turns.text: Yeah, so... I'm gonna wait and see what happens there... But that sounds great, yeah.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Okay.  So is that a yes or a no?

turns.speaker: RENISE
turns.text: I think I was very clear, Ted. If everything else falls apart, maybe.

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Piggyback ride.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I don't mind. If you think he can hold me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We're here, Warren. You wanna get off?

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Giddy-up.

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Franks and beans!

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Jesus, I think her brother spotted me.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: How are you doing, Warren?

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Good, Ted. Piggy back ride?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm gonna take a rain check.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See you, Warren.

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Huh...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: See you, Warren.

turns.speaker: WARREN
turns.text: Bye, Ted.

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: Which is exactly what they appear to be preparing to do, Mr. President. We're tracking 26 ships inbound to Cuba. There's no sign they're changing course. The closest ships, the Gagarin and the Kimovsk, will make the quarantine line by this time tomorrow.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: We're concerned about the possibility of an incident with an innocent cargo carrier. If it turns ugly, the Russians could use an ugly incident and bad world opinion as leverage to force us to remove the quarantine.

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: We've been hailing the Groznyy for the last hour, Mr. Secretary. The Groznyy refuses to stop.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: Carrying out our mission, Mr. Secretary. If you don't mind, we're very busy right now. We need to be able to do our jobs.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: Admiral, I asked you a question.

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: Yes, Captain, you may proceed. Clear your guns.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: What --

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: Starshells.

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: Get out of our way, Mr. Secretary. The navy has been running blockades since the days of John Paul Jones.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: I believe the President made it clear that there would be no firing on ships without his express permission.

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: With all due respect, Mr. Secretary, we were not firing on the ship. Firing on a ship means attacking the ship. We were not attacking the ship. We were firing over it.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: This was not the President's intention when he gave that order. What if the Soviets don't see the distention? What if they make the same mistake I just did?  There will be no firing anything near ANY Soviet ships without my express permission, is that understood, Admiral?

turns.speaker: ADMIRAL ANDERSON
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: MCNAMARA
turns.text: And I will only issue such instructions when ordered to by the President.  John Paul Jones... you don't understand a thing, do you, Admiral?

turns.speaker: DOBRYNIN
turns.text: This private assurance represents the word of the Highest Authority?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: DOBRYNIN
turns.text: And it can be relayed beyond Comrade Khruschev's ears to the top circles of my government

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Of course. Our pledge can be relayed to any government official Secretary Khruschev sees fit to satisfy.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: With the caveat that it is not made public in any way, shape or form.  And we must have an answer tomorrow at the latest. I cannot stress this point enough.

turns.speaker: DOBRYNIN
turns.text: Tomorrow...

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Tomorrow...

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Where the hell are you?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Jesus Christ, guys. What the hell's Khruschev thinking?

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Did you have any indication of this from Georgi? Any possible warning or sense of motivation?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Complete snowjob. And then we went out and told the country they weren't putting missiles into Cuba.  By the way, you realize we just lost the midterms.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: He's right, Jack. Taylor is saying we may have some time. We've got to use it.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: So if there are alternatives that make sense -- and I'm not saying there are -- we need 'em. Need 'em fast.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What about the allies? Congress? I think we may need to start letting key people know. And they're all scattered across the country for the campaign. We're going to need to get the U.N. staff in and warmed up. Jesus... I don't even know if we've got secure communications with half our embassies since that the Soviets got that cryptographer of ours.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: We can't worry about everything right now. We've got to figure out what we're going to do before we worry about how we do it.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: As if dealing with the Russians wasn't hard enough, we gotta worry about our own house.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Tonight, listening to Taylor and Acheson, I kept seeing Burke and Dulles telling me all I had to do was sign on the dotted line. The invasion would succeed. Castro would be gone. Just like that. Easy.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: There's still no sign they know that we know about the missiles. Been a lot of cloud cover; probably think we aren't getting any good product.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: We keep 'em in the dark as long as we can. But I sure as hell am going to test him.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Lying bastard. Lied to my face.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We're split down the middle. If I held a vote I think airstrike would beat blockade by a vote or two.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I want a consensus, Bobby. Consensus. Either air strike or blockade. Something everyone'll stand by even if they don't like it. I need it by Saturday. Make it happen.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What if I can't?

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Well, I'm not.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Then you'll call, right?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Goddamn Stevenson. Jesus. Peace at any price. You'd think nobody learned anything from World War Two.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Somebody had to say it. I respect Adlai for having the guts to risk looking like an appeaser.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We have to pull him. He's not going to be able to handle the Soviets in front of the U.N. Zorin will eat him alive.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: We've got bigger problems right now.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We're going to have to stop a ship eventually, show the quarantine's got teeth, or we'll prove McCone right.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: McNamara's on his way back here now. We need to pick the right ship. No subs. No armed boarding parties either. We need a little more time to figure this one out.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: He gets it, but he's pissed.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: That's all well and good, but what do we say to 'em?

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: We were just debating who had it worse, us or George Washington and his guys.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: He didn't have to worry about nuclear weapons.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Yeah, but the country didn't even exist as a country yet. It was a mess, and he didn't have a leg to stand on.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: How does a guy get a rep like that?

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Doesn't matter to me. If I went down in history like Adams, I'd die happy. All they say about him today is --

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Who gives a shit about the midterms now? The Soviets are putting nuclear weapons ninety miles away from us.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: You mean there's something more important than votes? Didn't think I'd live to see the day, Ken.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: The other thing is...

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: ...I know. CIA and the military fucked us on the Bay of Pigs.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: They're going to be pressing for a military solution soon. We can't afford to let them ram their agenda down our throats. We need to come with options other than air strikes so we have some sort of choice here.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We got a bunch of smart guys. We lock 'em up together in there, kick 'em in the ass til they come up with options.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: I'll do it.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: It's too politicized with you in there, anyway. They need to be able to stick their necks out.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: It'll be the principals, a couple of the key guys from each department: the Executive Committee of the National Security Council. We'll call it EXCOM.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Jack, I'm as conniving as they come, but a sneak attack is just wrong.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: He's right. And things are happening too fast. It smells like the Bay of Pigs all over again.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What happened to speak when spoken to?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Give it a rest. You were thinking the same thing, just didn't have the guts to take the heat.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Jesus...

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Rescind the order. Can all the Chiefs. Put Nitze, Gilpatric and the Undersecretaries in charge.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: We can't do that, Bobby.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Adlai's too weak! We have to convince Jack to pull him, get McCloy in there.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: You can't take him out this late in the game.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Zorin will eat him alive!

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Then talk to your brother, goddamn it. The two of you don't need any advice to get into trouble.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: What's gotten into you?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Oh, still sore about this.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Something your father would've come up with.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: My father --

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: -- I'm just trying to make a point. This idea is that fucking bad.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Adlai can handle Zorin. He knows the inning and the score.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: He better. Because nobody thinks he's up to this. Nobody.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Where've you been? We've been trying to find you all morning.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Helen and I went out for breakfast. EXCOM's not supposed to convene til eight.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We just got a second letter from Khruschev. The deal's off.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We're getting everyone together as fast as we can.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: What does the letter say?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: They want us to take our missiles out of Turkey along with the no invasion pledge. It looks like Fomin was a ploy after all, and they were just stalling for time.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: And Jack wants to trade the missiles in Turkey.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: The Jupiters are obsolete. They were supposed to have been dismantled last summer anyway --

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: -- Jesus, Mary and Joseph. I told you how stupid it was to float the Lippman article! But you wouldn't listen to me. What if there hasn't been a coup at all? What if it's you two who invited that second letter by raising the possibility of a trade?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: All right, so maybe we overestimated how reasonable this trade would look. Okay? You happy? So now what?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: So now you've got to talk him out of it. And then we've got to figure out an acceptable political solution.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: And if there has been a coup and there is no acceptable political solution?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: We gave so much to get here. I don't know. Sometimes I think what the hell did we do it for?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Because we knew we could do a better job than everyone else.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Slow down. Smell that?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Smoke.

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Just wanted to see for myself.  They're burning their documents.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: BOBBY
turns.text: Kenny. It's over.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Hey, Mac. You're up bright and early.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: No, Ken. I need to see him now...

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: What's it about?

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: Cuba.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Helen just asked me what sort of arrangements we have for the families.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: I just checked myself.  They're being issued identity cards. Call comes, and evacuation officers meet them at pre-arranged departure areas. They go by helicopter to Mount Weather. We meet them there.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: What did you think of Lippman's column this morning?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I think it's a bad idea.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: You gotta stop 'em. We know it's Jack and Bobby's idea -- they leaked it to Lippman. The military guys are going ape, and they're not alone.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Then they should speak up.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: Christ, Ken, you know it's not that easy.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Yes it is.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: No it isn't. They don't trust the people that feel this way. But these people are right. And the Kennedys are wrong.  We need you to tell 'em, Kenny. They'll listen to you.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: Jack and Bobby are good men. But it takes a certain character, moral toughness to stand up to --

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: -- You listen to me. Nobody, nobody, talks about my friends that way. You're fucking here right now because of the Kennedys. They may be wrong. They make mistakes. But they're not weak. The weak ones are these 'people' who can't speak their own minds.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: You know I don't mean they're weak.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: The sun came up today.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: It shouldn't have. But it did.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Every day the sun comes up... says something about us.

turns.speaker: BUNDY
turns.text: Says what, Kenny?

turns.speaker: SCALI
turns.text: I am instructed to tell you that the American Government would respond favorably to an offer along the lines you have discussed. If this solution were raised at the U.N. by Ambassador Zorin, he would find a favorable reply from Ambassador Stevenson.

turns.speaker: FOMIN
turns.text: So I understand you correctly. If the missiles in Cuba were dismantled, returned to the Soviet Union, and a guarantee was made not to reintroduce them, the United States would be prepared to guarantee that it would never invade Cuba?

turns.speaker: SCALI
turns.text: That is correct.

turns.speaker: FOMIN
turns.text: This is from the Highest Authority?

turns.speaker: SCALI
turns.text: Yes. From the Highest Authority. There are two conditions. The U.N. must be allowed to inspect the removal of the missiles.

turns.speaker: FOMIN
turns.text: And, of course, the U.N. must be allowed to observe the redeployment of forces from the American Southeast.

turns.speaker: FOMIN
turns.text: And the second condition?

turns.speaker: SCALI
turns.text: Time is of the essence.

turns.speaker: FOMIN
turns.text: John. How much time?

turns.speaker: SCALI
turns.text: 48 hours. In 48 hours there can be no deals.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Max.

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: McCone's been notified and is coming back from the West coast. Carter's here, though.

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: We have high confidence in the expanded air strike option.  The problem, Mr. President, is that it's a short-term solution. Khruschev can send more missiles next month. The Chiefs and I believe we should follow up the air strikes with the full version of OPLAN 316.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: An invasion...

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes, sir. We can be sure we get all the missiles, and we remove Castro so this can never happen again.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Is this the Chiefs' recommendation?

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes, sir. Our best option is to commence the strikes before the missiles are operational. The invasion happens eight days later.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: How long until the army is ready?

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: We've just begun the mobilization under cover of a pre-arranged exercise, sir. We're looking at another week and a half, Mr. President.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Guess we can't blame Khruschev for a few patriotic farmers. And the ships?

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: Still heading for Cuba.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: All right. Then I guess it's time.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: -- I have the authority. I am the commander-in-chief of the United States, and I say when we go to war!

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: We are not at war, sir, not until we're at DEFCON 1.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: General, the Joint Chiefs have just signaled our intent to escalate to the Soviets. You have signaled an escalation which I had no wish to signal, and which I did not approve.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: So which one of you geniuses can tell me how to explain ourselves to the world? How do we work with them if there's been a hard-line coup?

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: Mr. President, there is another possibility we haven't considered. This may not be a coup at all.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Then we have no choice.  General, issue the warning orders to our forces. They will be prepared to execute the air strikes Monday morning and the follow-on invasion according to the schedule thereafter. I'll need the official release orders on my desk Sunday night.

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: Understood, sir. We need to step up the overflights, finalize our pilots' target folders in order to be able to carry out the strikes.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Does this attack on our plane represent a definitive, intentional escalation on the part of the Soviets?

turns.speaker: GENERAL TAYLOR
turns.text: The Soviets are in control of the SAMs. It's hard to believe with their centralized command structure that it could be an accidental launch.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: Don't forget, Mrs. Higgins wants to talk to you this afternoon about Kevin. You need to do something about this.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Kids are supposed to get detention.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: When are you going to be home?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I don't know, Helen. I want you to keep the kids close tomorrow. Leave the T.V. on, sleep with it on in the bedroom until I tell you you can turn it off.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Nothing. Nothing you don't know about. Tomorrow's the big day. Just have the car ready to go if I call or if the Civil Defense Warning comes on.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: What happens to you? I'm not leaving without you.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I'll be evacuated with the President.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: If you're home it means either Jack and Bobby have finally figured out what a con man you are and fired you, or --

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: -- we got a back channel communication from Khruschev this evening feeling us out about a deal. He confirmed it just a little while ago in a letter to the President. I think we've won.

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: A thing like this... who could even think of winning?

turns.speaker: HELEN
turns.text: I saw you out there. You want him to call you back, need you.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: No. I'm glad I'm home.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: How's my favorite President?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Busy. But you've got his heart.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: I want an hour with him.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I said his heart, not his attention.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Three weeks before midterm elections? You need me.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Well. There is a new civil rights initiative he wants to talk about.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: I'm doing a piece on Skybolt. I hear Macmillan's meeting with him in Nassau.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Pretending there isn't a problem won't fix it. He can clear the air on Anglo American relations.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Forget it, Scotty.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Let him talk to me, he makes Macmillan look good, I print it, the British public likes it, Macmillan owes you.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: It's Tuesday. You said to call. When do I get my 45 minutes?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Tell you what. We're in Connecticut tomorrow for Ribicoff. I'll get you up front with him during the flight.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Deal.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Kenny! What happened? They didn't let me up front, said the President was on the phone the whole time.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: He was.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: Yeah? Who was he talking to? Acheson? Come on, O'Donnell, everyone's wondering what's going on. What's Acheson doing in town? And don't give me some bullshit about DNC think tanks. Acheson's Mr. Cold War.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Why don't you ask him yourself? You can have him on the way home.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: I'm giving you a chance here: talk to me. You can influence how this thing unfolds.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: There are major rail disruptions in the South, two airborne divisions are on alert. That exercise is an invasion.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Well, you know how Bobby has it in for the State of Mississippi.

turns.speaker: RESTON
turns.text: This is about Cuba.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Secretary of Defense...

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Dean Rusk!

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Wrong, and you get to wax my car.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Hey, sport. You winning?

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: I guess you won't be coming home tonight.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: I, uh...

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Get back out there, kid. Remember to hit 'em hard.

turns.speaker: KEVIN
turns.text: What about you? Where are you going?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Back to work.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I was eating that.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: No you weren't.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: I was, you bastard.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: So what've we got today?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Today, for your information, is Pulaski Day. We're going to Buffalo...

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Still think Cuba isn't important?

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Not as far as the election goes.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Should be here any minute.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: No choice. This is going to cost lives any way we go. Do nothing, and it could be 80 million of ours. We have to get rid of those missiles.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: There've got to be alternatives to just going out and bombing them.

turns.speaker: THE PRESIDENT
turns.text: Okay. Kenny and I only show for the meetings you call us into. Impress us. And do it fast.  You're in charge of keeping this quiet. If word gets out before we know what we're going to do, there'll be panic. And it'll ruin any chance of surprise if we decide to hit them.

turns.speaker: KENNY
turns.text: Then we need to do a few things right away. No Pierre. He knows, the press knows. You're going to have to keep up your schedule -- your movements are followed too closely. And we need to get these guys out of the White House. George Ball's got a conference room at State.  Reconvene over there this afternoon, come back here tonight.
